articles.headline: Companies Embrace Low Interest Rates by Selling Bonds to Raise Billions
articles.snippet: Verizon Communications sold $49 billion worth of bonds in the largest investment grade corporate bond sale ever, trumping the previous record set by Apple’s $17 billion bond sale in April.
articles.abstract: Verizon Communications sold $49 billion worth of bonds in the largest investment grade corporate bond sale ever, trumping the previous record set by Apple’s $17 billion bond sale in April.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:05 p.m. | For companies looking to raise money through the debt markets, and the bankers egging them on, it seems no sum is too large.

articles.headline: Chair Pitched as Answer to New Ways We Sit on Job
articles.snippet: Steelcase says we need chairs to accommodate the strange new positions we work in these days, but its new model may offer only a slight improvement.
articles.abstract: Steelcase says we need chairs to accommodate the strange new positions we work in these days, but its new model may offer only a slight improvement.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first time I had to buy a mattress, I remember being shocked at how much it cost. “Ah, but just remember,” the sales representative told me, “you’re going to spend a third of your life on it. Isn’t it worth investing in something you’ll use for a third of your life?”

articles.headline: Tina Brown to Leave The Daily Beast and Publishing
articles.snippet: The magazine editor said she would start a company to build up her Women in the World conferences.
articles.abstract: The magazine editor said she would start a company to build up her Women in the World conferences.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tina Brown is leaving the world of publishing.

articles.headline: Facebook Privacy Change Is Subject of F.T.C. Inquiry
articles.snippet: After a storm of negative comments from users, the Federal Trade Commission has begun an inquiry into Facebook’s latest privacy policies.
articles.abstract: After a storm of negative comments from users, the Federal Trade Commission has begun an inquiry into Facebook’s latest privacy policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook, which has repeatedly tripped over its own feet when changing its privacy practices, has stumbled yet again.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Edward Wyatt

articles.headline: As Obama Pauses Action, Putin Takes Center Stage
articles.snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin has, at least for now, made Russia indispensable in containing the conflict in Syria.
articles.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin has, at least for now, made Russia indispensable in containing the conflict in Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin has been many things to President Obama: a partner at times, an irritant more often, the host of the elusive Edward J. Snowden and “the bored kid in the back of the classroom” who offered so little on the administration’s foreign policy goals that Mr. Obama canceled plans to hold a summit meeting in Moscow last week.

articles.headline: Unions’ Misgivings on Health Law Burst Into View
articles.snippet: Labor leaders meeting in Los Angeles approved a sharply worded resolution that demanded changes to the federal health care law.
articles.abstract: Labor leaders meeting in Los Angeles approved a sharply worded resolution that demanded changes to the federal health care law.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When President Obama phoned the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. last month, he shared some news that the labor leader had long wanted to hear — the administration would propose measures to reduce workplace exposure to disease-causing silica dust.
articles.byline: By Steven Greenhouse and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: A Rare Public View of Obama’s Pivots on Policy in Syria Confrontation
articles.snippet: President Obama’s handling of his confrontation with Syria has been an unusual instance of a commander in chief seemingly thinking out loud and changing his mind on the fly.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s handling of his confrontation with Syria has been an unusual instance of a commander in chief seemingly thinking out loud and changing his mind on the fly.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama strode into the Rose Garden last month after a week of increasing tension over Syria’s use of chemical weapons, many assumed it was to announce that the attack that had been broadly hinted at by his own aides had begun. Instead, he turned the decision over to Congress. And when Mr. Obama appeared on television Tuesday night, a speech initially intended to promote force made the argument for diplomacy.

articles.headline: New York Regulator Sees Abuse Increasing Under New Insurance Rules
articles.snippet: Benjamin Lawsky, the New York financial regulator, has left a multistate test of a framework for insurers’ asset reserves, saying industry “gamesmanship” was only getting worse.
articles.abstract: Benjamin Lawsky, the New York financial regulator, has left a multistate test of a framework for insurers’ asset reserves, saying industry “gamesmanship” was only getting worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: Several big life insurers are going to have to set aside a total of at least $4 billion because New York regulators believe they have been manipulating new rules meant to make sure they have adequate reserves to pay out claims.

articles.headline: Recall Vote on Guns Exposes Rift in Colorado’s Blue Veneer
articles.snippet: Democrats control the state legislature and the governor’s mansion, but a recall campaign exposed the party to popular anger as voters ousted two state senators who supported gun laws.
articles.abstract: Democrats control the state legislature and the governor’s mansion, but a recall campaign exposed the party to popular anger as voters ousted two state senators who supported gun laws.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — When Colorado passed a series of tough gun restrictions last winter, Democrats and gun control advocates hailed it as a sign of changing attitudes in a Western swing state. But moments after a pivotal vote in the state Senate, a Republican lawmaker named Greg Brophy warned that Colorado’s independent-leaning voters would rebel against the new laws.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Dan Frosch

articles.headline: Afghan Army Struggles in District Under Siege
articles.snippet: The Sangin district in Afghanistan offers a troubling portrait of life where the Taliban decide to make their mark and the Americans no longer fight.
articles.abstract: The Sangin district in Afghanistan offers a troubling portrait of life where the Taliban decide to make their mark and the Americans no longer fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANGIN, Afghanistan — Some days, the Afghan soldiers worry that the mud walls around their headquarters in this embattled district are barely enough to keep the Taliban out. Perhaps more problematic is that the crumbling facade appears to be keeping the soldiers in.

articles.headline: Long Battle for Dell Ends in Victory for Founder
articles.snippet: Dell shareholders voted on Thursday to approve the computer company’s $24.9 billion sale to its founder, ending a monthslong slog that included fierce opposition from some investors.
articles.abstract: Dell shareholders voted on Thursday to approve the computer company’s $24.9 billion sale to its founder, ending a monthslong slog that included fierce opposition from some investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: After months of hurdles, Michael S. Dell is finally poised to buy full control of the company that bears his name, in his biggest move yet to turn around the computer maker’s fortunes as its industry goes through tectonic shifts.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Quentin Hardy

articles.headline: Boehner Seeking Democrats’ Help on Fiscal Talks
articles.snippet: As Speaker John A. Boehner sought a deal to avert a government shutdown and raise the debt ceiling, a bloc of Republicans demanded a delay in the federal health care law, which the White House called “a nonstarter.”
articles.abstract: As Speaker John A. Boehner sought a deal to avert a government shutdown and raise the debt ceiling, a bloc of Republicans demanded a delay in the federal health care law, which the White House called “a nonstarter.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With Congress momentarily freed from the Syrian crisis, lawmakers plunged back into their bitter fiscal standoff on Thursday as Speaker John A. Boehner appealed to the Obama administration and Democratic leaders to help him resolve divisions in the Republican ranks that could lead to a government shutdown by month’s end.
